Hi Colin,

         Can you explain a little more what you mean by generic in 
this instance.  e.g. can you give examples of how implementations of 
those interfaces might vary, when different versions would be used, 
whether different versions would be expected to talk to one another...

         Remember we use a variety of different languages and the 
exact meaning of some terms (e.g. "interface" may vary a little).

         Ian

At 22:16 04/12/2005, you wrote:
>Quiz time.
>
>I'm thinking of making the SharpNeat neuro-evolution 'engine' a bit more
>re-usable and generic. Right now I have an IGenome interface defined,
>instances of which can of course be decoded (translated, developed or
>whatever) into something that implements INetwork (which more generally
>could be IPhenome I suppose). In the past there have been discussions
>about the best place for the decoding algorithm, ideally IGenome and
>IPhenome would be totally abstract and a single abstract decoder
>algorithm would act as the glue between the two systems. In reality a
>custom decode algorithm is usually required, at least in the very
>general case where IGenomes and IPhenomes could be absolutely anything
>you want them to be.
>
>My solution then is to package up IGenome and IPhenome into a higher
>level interface/class alongside the decoding algorithm. This new package
>can then (potentially) be plugged into the NEAT engine in a completely
>abstract manner. My question then is, what is a good name for this
>interface? ISupernome perhaps? :)
>
>I'm doing a bit of web surfing to try and find an appropriate term from
>biology, but I've uncovered nothing so far. If you think about it though
>in biological terms this would be the system that consists of the
>genome, the phenome and the cellular machinery that decodes the DNA/RNA
>and that builds proteins etc.
>
>Cheers,
>
>Colin.
>
>

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
